Question: Korea's services account recorded a surplus of how much in the first nine months of this year?

Kelly performed it on X-Factor as a duet with Melanie Amaro.A version of the song, recorded by the Halifax community choir, was used as the backing track to a 2012 UK TV advertisement for the Halifax Bank.On October 13, 2012, when the Space Shuttle Endeavour was being transferred from Los Angeles International Airport to the California Science Center through the streets of Los Angeles, the recording was played as the shuttle left The Forum, and the song was performed live by James Ingram later that day at Debbie Allen's live show celebrating the Endeavour's arrival at the corner of Crenshaw Blvd and Martin Luther King Blvd.

Question: Who composed Jingle Bell Rock?
Sentence(s): "Jingle Bell Rock" was composed by Joseph Carleton Beal (1900–1967), and James Ross Boothe (1917–1976).Beal was a Massachusetts-born public relations man and longtime resident of South Ocean Avenue in Atlantic City, New Jersey, and Boothe was a Texan writer in the advertising business.

Question: Where did the funds for the tower come from?

It is often referred to as the "lost" land of Disneyland.

Sentence(s): The Tang and Song Dynasties did not build any walls in the region substantially.

Question: When did Zambia re-open their border?

Sentence(s): The Yellowstone National Park Archives maintain collections of historical records of Yellowstone and the National Park Service.

Question: What further acellerated the uplift of the Sierra?
Sentence(s): Pleistocene glaciers further accelerated this process and the larger ones transported the resulting talus and till from valley floors.Numerous vertical joint planes controlled where and how fast erosion took place.

Question: How much sunlight do north-facing slopes receive compared to other slopes?
Sentence(s): North-facing slopes receive about one-third the normal amount of sunlight, so plants growing there are similar to plants found at higher elevations, or in more northern latitudes.

Question: Why did Borglum choose this particular site?
Sentence(s): Borglum selected Mount Rushmore as the site for several reasons.
The rock of the mountain is composed of smooth, fine-grained granite.
The durable granite erodes only every 10,000 years, thus was more than sturdy enough to support the sculpture and its long-term exposure.
The mountain's height of above sea level made it suitable, and because it faces the southeast, the workers also had the advantage of sunlight for most of the day.

Question: How many pieces are in the Lego set of the Space Needle?

Sentence(s): Public access to the balcony surrounding the torch has been barred for safety reasons since 1916.

Question: What remained of seaworld after it ended
Sentence(s): Some of the SeaWorld property remained intact, albeit hidden or modified.
What remained included the former seal and sea lion area, the Ski Stadium (to be used in a Lumberjack show in 2006), the Aquarium (to be used for unknown purposes), and two movie theater houses/simulators, once housing 3D/4D movies.

Question: What was Minetown modeled after?
Sentence(s): Minetown was modeled to resemble a mining town, just as its name says.

Question: When was the original park sold?
Sentence(s): The original park, in Arlington (between Dallas and Fort Worth) was sold in 1966 to a subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which was actively pursuing non-railroad investments in an effort to diversify its sources of income.

Question: When was the Amesbury Archer buried?
Sentence(s): A teenage boy buried approximately 1550 BC was raised near the Mediterranean Sea; a metal worker from 2300 BC dubbed the "Amesbury Archer" grew up near the alpine foothills of Germany; and the "Boscombe Bowmen" probably arrived from Wales or Brittany, France.

Question: What was connected to the Colosseum by an underground passage?

Sentence(s): Although Van Gogh is best known for his landscapes, he seemed to find painting portraits his greatest ambition.

Sentence(s): The lion has long been a symbol associated with the sun in ancient Near Eastern civilizations.

Question: Who did Van Gogh write in 1888 expressing his desire to paint the night sky?

Question: Who organizes the World Cup?

Question: When did Scotland pass the Football Act?
Sentence(s): In 1424, the Parliament of Scotland passed a Football Act that stated "it is statut and the king forbiddis that na man play at the fut ball under the payne of iiij d" – in other words, playing football was made illegal, and punishable by a fine of four pence.By 1608, the local authorities in Manchester were complaining that: "With the ffotebale...hath beene greate disorder in our towne of Manchester we are told, and glasse windowes broken yearlye and spoyled by a companie of lewd and disordered persons ..." That same year, the word"football" was used disapprovingly by William Shakespeare.

Question: What is baseball?
Sentence(s): Baseball is a bat-and-ball game played between two teams of nine players who take turns batting and fielding.The offense attempts to score runs by hitting a ball thrown by the pitcher with a bat and moving counter-clockwise around a series of four bases: first, second, third and home plate.

Question: Which is the defending team getting possession of a loose ball?

Question: Why wasn't Japan strongly affected by the Great Depression?

Econometric studies have identified the fiscal stimulus as especially effective.The devaluation of the currency had an immediate effect.

The deficit spending proved to be most profound.
